data.text: Long Distance Touring: How Many Hours Per Day?

I am planning my first long trip tour. I wonder how many hours per day I should plan for bicycling. I think is harder to plan distance because it depends on so many things, elevation, packing, surface, e t c.
So many factors: distance between campgrounds and supplies.

data.text: The main competing factors are eating and sleeping. Don't underestimate the eating. The distance you cover is largely down to the amount of time you can give to the saddle. You will probably find that coffee is your best friend waking up in the morning. Depending on whether you are camping or not you can probably comfortably spend between 5-7 hours in the saddle.

data.text: In terms of riding hours, we have found that 4-5 hours is about the norm, more than 5hrs is a hard day, and more than 6 hrs is really tough going. On steep mountain terrain with few towns and features a 6hr day may be more common as you just keep on riding, but it is still a tough day. Remember that on most tours you will want some time for simple sightseeing. In terms of distances, a 15-20kmh average speed means that 5hrs is about 75-100km, which is the sort of longer distances we do on our tours.

data.text: I am old and slow, and the terrain has some big hills. The workload also affects how many hours in the saddle. Lots of hills may also reduce the number of hours as well as the distance that I am willing to ride, as I tend to take longer breaks for lunch etc. I also take time to look at anything interesting, and/or take photos. For me 4-5 hours pedal time seems to be the norm. With maybe a 6-6 1/2 hour riding day. This is 60+km per day, and I can easily maintain this day after day.
data.author: Mark Perry

data.text: Some days you feel good some days not so good. Your average Kilometers per day increases as you get fitter. Don't over analyse it just get on your bike and ride and your body will tell you when to stop. Of course you may reach a point of interest so then you stop earlier in the day. I have a rule that I stop for food coffee and a break roughly every 3 hours. For some reason this is about the spacing of small settlements and miss the opportunity may mean 3 hours to the next opportunity depending where you travelling.
data.author: Stephen Rackham

data.text: I just cycle until I have found a convenient place to stay that also more or less meets my objective to make progress ... or earlier if I feel like it. But I have often pressed on at about 3.30 in the afternoon having found a convenient place to stay, and then cursed myself for being a fool as night fell! I found 100km my usual daily distance which I thought was totally normal until I came across a group who were cycling 150-160km every day. They thought I was slow! I guess it completely depends on the individual, you need to sound out what's good for yourself.
